[Statement 3]: Studies found that bat activity was similar or higher over reservoirs and waste water treatment pools, heliponds and drainage ditches, retention ponds and farm/cattle ponds compared to over natural wetlands, nearby vineyards, surrounding forest or grassland/crops, trees and orchards.
[Statement 4]: One study in South Africa found a similar number of bat species over farm ponds and in grassland, crops, trees, vineyards or orchards.
[Statement 5]: Managing livestock water troughs as drinking resources for bats shows promise.
[Statement 6]: Two studies in the USA demonstrated that removing livestock modifications from water troughs resulted in bats drinking from the water troughs more frequently.
[Statement 7]: Studies found that larger, full water tanks surrounded by sparse vegetation had more bats drinking from them than smaller, half full tanks surrounded by no or dense vegetation.
[Statement 8]: Small dams can also provide effective habitat for bats.
[Statement 9]: One study in Portugal found that reservoirs created using small dams had greater activity of four bat species than the streams feeding into the reservoirs.
[Statement 10]: Wetland restoration showed positive results in one USA study.
[Statement 11]: Restoring wetlands increased overall bat activity.
[Statement 12]: Restored wetlands had similar bat activity to undisturbed wetlands.
[Statement 13]: No studies were found that specifically evaluated managing natural water bodies in arid areas to prevent desiccation for bat populations.

[Statement 1]: Several farming systems and practices show benefits for bat populations in agricultural landscapes.
[Statement 2]: Organic farming shows mixed but generally positive results for bat populations compared to conventional farming.
[Statement 3]: Studies found higher overall bat activity, bat feeding activity, Brazilian free-tailed bat activity, and activity of four out of seven bat species on organic farms.
[Statement 4]: Two studies found higher activity of Myotis species over water and rivers on organic farms.
[Statement 5]: One study found higher activity for two of three bat species over organic fields compared to conventionally managed fields.
[Statement 6]: Agroforestry systems, particularly those with varied shade cover, demonstrate clear benefits for bats.
[Statement 7]: Coffee plantations with varied shade cover had more bats captured and higher activity of forest bat species compared to plantations with a single shade species.
[Statement 8]: Shaded coffee, cacao and banana plantations had more bat species and higher bat diversity than plantations with a single shade species or no shade.
[Statement 9]: Silvopastoral systems using agroforestry combined with no chemicals resulted in great fruit-eating bats with higher body weights and body condition scores compared to bats in conventional farming areas.
[Statement 10]: Reducing chemical inputs benefits bat populations.
[Statement 11]: Farms using few or no chemicals showed different bat species compositions, higher diversity of insect-eating bat species in coffee agroforestry plantations, and higher overall bat activity compared to farms with high chemical inputs.
[Statement 12]: Agricultural landscapes with smaller fields had higher activity of six of seven bat species compared to landscapes with larger fields.
[Statement 13]: Hedges trimmed three or more years prior had more bat species and higher activity of two of eight bat species compared to recently trimmed hedges.
[Statement 14]: Tree plantations on agricultural land showed mixed results for bat populations.
[Statement 15]: Bat activity is generally lower in tree plantations compared to original forest and woodland remnants.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__In agricultural landscapes, which farming systems are most beneficial for bat populations?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Ex-situ bat conservation actions show varied outcomes and success rates.
[Statement 2]: For bat rehabilitation programs, 70-90% of hand-reared pipistrelle bats survived for at least 4-14 days after release into the wild.
[Statement 3]: Six of 21 hand-reared pipistrelle bats successfully joined wild bat colonies.
[Statement 4]: 13% of ringed hand-reared pipistrelle bats were found alive in bat boxes 38 days to almost four years after release.
[Statement 5]: Bats that flew in large flight cages for long periods before release survived for longer and were more active than bats that flew for short periods or in small enclosures.
[Statement 6]: For captive breeding programs, 6-100% of female bats captured in the wild successfully conceived, gave birth and reared young in captivity.
[Statement 7]: Survival rates for bat pups born in captivity ranged from 20-100% from between 10 days to adulthood.
[Statement 8]: Two of five bats and two of three bats born in captivity successfully gave birth to live young.
[Statement 9]: No studies were found that evaluated the effects of releasing captive-bred bats on bat populations.
[Statement 10]: No studies were found evaluating the breeding of bats in captivity specifically to supplement wild populations affected by white-nose syndrome.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__What are the outcomes and success rates associated with ex-situ bat conservation actions like captive breeding and rehabilitation?
